um you know of course most people think of cloud computing and maybe AWS in terms

that the complexity of maintaining particularly databases becomes
burdensome on application teams and so if you think about this life cycle of
innovation at AWS we've sort of thought started thinking about you know database as a service and we think about adopting
Cloud patterns you know we don't want to think about a database generically but understand you know is this really
relational is it non-relational is it primarily a cash uh problem we're trying
to solve is it a Hadoop infrastructure that I'm trying to maintain and run or
is it something focused more on on streaming or relational databases and so
for each of these different use cases you know we've essentially moved Beyond just compute and storage and have
managed Services where we can take your workload and match it to the right data pattern in terms of an engine and then
not just presenting you with the windows or Linux installation but actually taking care of the database meaning we
do the installation configuration the patching the backups the high availability planning all of these
things are super critical from a database administrator perspective but oftentimes we refer to them as
undifferentiated effort meaning that you know we want to have our DBA teams to focus on the application and then your
end user and your customer experience and not the infrastructure because we now provide that as part of our managed
service and then understand different workloads require different types of engines in terms of really driving the

whether the individual data point is a stream a file or an object we
essentially want to land it into the appropriate storage engine so if it's a transaction we have a relational database service if you're looking for
very high throughput reads and writes we have a nosql store called dynamodb and
then of course for data warehousing type applications we have a service called Amazon redshift which is essentially a
cloud powered data warehousing for applications that require Analytics
and then if you kind of build this out uh you know the piece that it always customers have asked for is hey you've

time regardless of the data format so of course this is what uh quicksite
is is targeted at we announced the preview back at re invent last October

and quick side is essentially a cloud-powered bi service at roughly
one-tenth the cost of traditional bi systems and I'll kind of break down each of these statements in terms of what we

and you know the tagline right it can be as low as nine dollars per user per month and this oftentimes is what really

consume data so we want to have equal interfaces whether it's a browser or if
it's a mobile device so if it's a tablet you know even a phone given the appropriate form factors but essentially

Mobile you know really have a mobile first strategy with a quick site as well
and then of course from an infrastructure perspective we'll go through some more details but you know
one of the the painful points of traditional FBI systems is hey how do I configure and install you know the

data sources that quick slide supports are natively installed as part of the service itself right so I don't have to

just of course enter the connect information in but not have to install the software for that and then through

technical details of the data source and the way the business sees it and of course overlay a security model for

of the data itself right so where the data source reside at what renaming have I done what calculations have I added

then I'll dive deep in a slide or two going forward but then we want to think about how we can enable fast and some in
this case super fast performance for those queries So In traditional bi tools right I need to really think about

will respond which means that I'll get reports rendered faster so with quick
site in addition to the user interface and the mobile experience we also have a
caching layer that we call Spice which is super fast parallel in-memory calculation engine
right so as we say you know add some spice to your data it should all good
things will happen right and so I'll talk more in detail here in a second but essentially think about an in-memory
column or database as a managed service so you just tell us the amount of data
and the number of users that can access it and we provision all the infrastructure behind the scenes for you
so it's horizontally scalable in memory column in our data store um and then the other thing is think
about uh this idea of you know how long it takes for an analyst to see a data

think about relational non-relational file and API data sources so of course
relational like redshift or SQL server or MySQL non-relational things like you
know dynamodb Cassandra API data sources can be things like Salesforce
Marketo but then just something as simple as a file sitting on S3 right can

structured to think about redshift as a consolidation point for this data and
then apply security or bucket policies on top of that data in terms of access controls this is just one example of a

so the other way to then think about this is that I've got all these different data sets I can combine it into S3 or to redshift

course load the data into the calculation engine or caching layer called spice to make available through

Innovation that quick slight really drives of course you know we think we hit on most of these bullet points we'll

then let's also think about okay well if 10 of my data is accessed 95 of the time
maybe it makes sense to take that 10 of the data from the relational Source put it into an in-memory columnar data store
and then have you know super fast or you might say millisecond type response time
excuse me from the from there but of course if it's not a relational Source if it's a file on S3 you know how do I
push a query down to a file system and so the ability to expand Beyond just relational sources I think is going to
be a really interesting use score use case for quicksite and then

of encryption Access Control where we have a SQL like interface so if
